sections.title: Dividend Taxes
sections.subtitle: Keep more of your dividend income

sections.title: How Dividends Are Taxed
sections.content:
Dividends are taxed differently depending on whether they're 'qualified' or 'ordinary':

Qualified Dividends: Taxed at favorable long-term capital gains rates (0%, 15%, or 20% depending on income). Most dividends from US companies held for 60+ days qualify.

Ordinary Dividends: Taxed as regular income (up to 37%). Includes dividends from REITs, MLPs, money market funds, and stocks held less than 60 days.

For most dividend investors, the majority of dividends are qualified and taxed at 15% (for incomes $44,625-$492,300 single / $89,250-$553,850 married in 2024).

points.title: 0% Rate
points.description: Single filers: Income up to $44,625. Married filing jointly: Up to $89,250. If you're in this bracket, qualified dividends are tax-free!

points.title: 15% Rate
points.description: Single: $44,626 - $492,300. Married: $89,251 - $553,850. This is where most dividend investors fall. A $10,000 dividend costs $1,500 in taxes.

points.title: 20% Rate
points.description: Single: Over $492,300. Married: Over $553,850. High earners also pay an additional 3.8% Net Investment Income Tax, making the effective rate 23.8%.

points.title: Ordinary Dividend Rate
points.description: REIT and MLP dividends are taxed as ordinary income—up to 37% plus state taxes. This is why REITs are best held in tax-advantaged accounts.

sections.title: Tax-Efficient Account Placement
sections.content:
Where you hold dividend stocks matters enormously for taxes:

Tax-Advantaged Accounts (IRA, 401k, Roth):
- No annual tax on dividends
- Best for: REITs, MLPs, high-yield stocks, frequent traders
- Roth IRA is ideal—dividends grow and are withdrawn tax-free

Taxable Brokerage Accounts:
- Dividends taxed annually (even if reinvested)
- Best for: Qualified dividend stocks, tax-efficient ETFs
- Consider tax-loss harvesting to offset dividend income

Optimal Strategy:
- Hold REITs and high-yield stocks in IRA/401k
- Hold qualified dividend stocks (like Dividend Aristocrats) in taxable accounts
- Maximize Roth contributions for tax-free dividend growth

sections.title: Tax-Loss Harvesting for Dividend Investors
sections.content:
Tax-loss harvesting means selling losing positions to offset gains and dividend income:

How It Works:
1. You receive $5,000 in dividends (taxable)
2. You have a stock with $5,000 in unrealized losses
3. Sell the losing stock to realize the $5,000 loss
4. The loss offsets your dividend income
5. Result: $0 taxable dividend income

Rules to Follow:
- Wash sale rule: Can't buy the same or 'substantially identical' stock within 30 days
- Can buy a similar (but not identical) ETF immediately
- Losses exceeding gains can offset up to $3,000 of ordinary income
- Excess losses carry forward to future years

This strategy is most valuable in taxable accounts with significant dividend income.

sections.title: The REIT Tax Trap
sections.content: REIT dividends are mostly taxed as ordinary income (up to 37%), not qualified dividends (15%). A 5% REIT yield in a taxable account might net only 3.15% after taxes for high earners. Always hold REITs in tax-advantaged accounts when possible.

sections.title: Tax-Efficient Dividend Investing
steps: Maximize contributions to tax-advantaged accounts (401k, IRA, Roth)
Hold REITs, MLPs, and high-yield stocks in IRA/401k
Hold qualified dividend stocks in taxable accounts
Consider municipal bond funds for tax-free income in taxable accounts
Harvest tax losses annually to offset dividend income
Hold dividend stocks for 60+ days to qualify for lower tax rates
Consider Roth conversions to create tax-free dividend income in retirement
Consult a tax professional for complex situations

sections.title: State Taxes on Dividends
sections.content:
Don't forget state taxes! Most states tax dividends as ordinary income:

No State Income Tax: Alaska, Florida, Nevada, South Dakota, Texas, Washington, Wyoming (plus New Hampshire and Tennessee for investment income)

High Tax States: California (13.3%), New York (10.9%), New Jersey (10.75%)

If you live in a high-tax state, the combined federal + state tax on dividends can exceed 25-30%. This makes tax-advantaged accounts even more valuable.

Some states offer tax breaks for dividends from in-state companies or municipal bonds. Check your state's specific rules.

sections.title: Key Takeaway
sections.content: Taxes can significantly reduce your dividend income. Use tax-advantaged accounts strategically, understand the difference between qualified and ordinary dividends, and consider tax-loss harvesting. A little tax planning can save thousands annually.

sections.title: Next Steps
sections.content: You now understand dividend taxation and tax-efficient strategies. In the final lesson, we'll cover common dividend investing mistakes and how to avoid them, plus a summary of everything you've learned.
